awd_titl_txt: CAREER:  Thermal stress and intertidal zonation:  The neglected role of food supply
awd_abstract_narration:
This CAREER grant uses a combination of laboratory studies, computer modeling, and field experiments to test the relative influence of temperature stress and energy limitation on the upper vertical limit of an intertidal barnacle (Balanus glandula). Understanding the mechanisms by which temperature limits an organism's success is critical to generating accurate predictions of the effect of climate change on biological systems.  Past work in this field has emphasized the direct physiological stress of extreme temperatures, but it is unclear if such extreme conditions limit species in the wild.  Alternately, animals may simply lack enough energy to defend against thermal extremes that they could otherwise tolerate.  This work has three main objectives:  1) to extend an existing modeling approach in physiology (Dynamic Energy Budget) for use with intertidal species, which alternate daily between marine and terrestrial conditions, 2) to use the model, in conjunction with field experiments, to test the hypothesis that energy limitation, rather than direct thermal stress, limits the success of B. glandula in the wild; and, 3) to use field and laboratory measurements to explore how thermal tolerance and success differ between barnacle populations from California and Washington.  Altogether, these projects will improve our understanding of the thermal physiology of B. glandula, specifically, and of the role of energy limitation in thermal stress, more generally.

The integrated education plan of this CAREER grant contains three specific objectives:  1) to use research opportunities to attract and retain students in biology majors, 2) to improve the retention and performance of women and minority undergraduates in an introductory biology course, and 3) to improve the understanding of science by the general college population. The grant activities will include: generating new research opportunities for undergraduate and high school students, the piloting of a research experience program for sophomore-level students, the establishment of a peer-study program for students in an introductory biology course, and the development of a new course for non-science majors that emphasizes scientific literacy.  The educational effectiveness of these programs will be rigorously tested and the results will inform the future teaching activities of the PI, her department, and the greater academic science community. The broader impacts of this CAREER grant will be 1) broadening the participation of women and under-represented minorities in science, 2) improving biology education and the educational skills of the PI, 3) increasing public scientific literacy, and 4) informing our understanding of the biological consequences of global climate change, a critical societal need.

por.por_cntn:
This CAREER grant used a combination of laboratory studies, computer modeling, and field experiments to explore the relative influence of food supply and air and water temperatures  on the success of an intertidal barnacle (Balanus glandula). Understanding the mechanisms by which temperature limits an organism's success is critical to generating accurate predictions of the effect of climate change on biological systems. This study took a novel approach by examining energy demand and use of individual barnacles across a range of environmental conditions.  The work had three main objectives: 1) to extend an existing modeling approach in physiology (energy budget models) for use with intertidal species, which alternate daily between marine and terrestrial conditions, 2) to use the model, in conjunction with field experiments, to test the hypothesis that energy limitation, rather than direct thermal stress, limits the success of B. glandula in the wild; and, 3) to use field and laboratory measurements to explore how thermal tolerance and success differ between barnacle populations from California and Washington.

 

The main outcomes of this project were as follows:

  • A field transplant experiment showed that food benefitted all shore heights, contrary to our hypothesis that greater food would be most beneficial on the high shore
  • Laboratory studies of energy demand in air and water demonstrated that aerial respiration of B. glandula can exceed aquatic respiration, suggesting that B. glandula is not oxygen-limited during emersion.
  • A comparison of thermal performance curves among three populations of B. glandula, spanning approximately 15 degrees of latitude revealed that a population?s thermal physiology is more closely tied to the water temperatures of its environment than the low tide temperatures.  Because water temperatures and low tide temperatures are uncorrelated across the Northeastern Pacific, this means that the populations most vulnerable to warming temperatures under climate change are unlikely to be concentrated at lower latitudes, but rather will occur where low tide thermal conditions are most greatly divergent from water temperatures.
  • We developed the first energy budget model for an intertidal species that incorporates both aerial and aquatic thermal physiology.  By separately accounting for the aerial and aquatic thermal environments, we were able to demonstrate that warming water temperatures under climate change may actually ameliorate the negative impacts of warming air temperatures.

Together these results paint a complex picture of the interactive effects of aerial and aquatic environments on the performance of intertidal species.  They provide important insights for researchers, conservation professional, and shellfishery managers interested in mitigating the negative impacts of climate change on intertidal species and communities.

The integrated education plan of this CAREER grant contained three specific objectives: 1) to use research opportunities to attract and retain students in biology majors, 2) to improve the retention and performance of women and minority undergraduates in introductory science courses, and 3) to improve the understanding of science by the general population.

 

The main outcomes of the educational projects were as follows:

  • The project led to the training of 32 undergraduate students in biological research methods and activities related to the project, along with 3 postdoctoral scholars.
  • The project included a pilot study of a Supplemental Instruction (SI) program in introductory science courses.  We found that attending an SI program led to higher final exam grades in introductory science courses for both students from groups under-represented in science and all students more generally.
  • The project also fostered a new collaboration between the Principal Investigator and a local Title 1 elementary school.  This has directly improved the teaching of science to the diverse group of students enrolled in this school.
